newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore HSFO seen steady, VLCC into China heard.
newsitem.headline: Singapore HSFO seen steady, VLCC into China heard.

text.p: High sulphur fuel oil prices were assessed steady on Friday with traders vague on near term market direction amid thin talks, traders said.
Most Japanese traders were away for holidays, keeping market discussion thin, they said.
High sulphur 180-cst fuel oil levels were assessed at $123/$125 per tonne Friday, unchanged from Tuesday -- the most recent trading day -- for prompt loading barrels.
January swaps was quoted Friday at a steady but wider $120.50/$122.00 against Tuesday's $121/$121.50. February swaps were quoted at $117.00/$118.00, unchanged from Tuesday.
Fuel oil 380-cst was last assessed Tuesday at $116.00/$118.00 per tonne.
"It is difficult to assess market direction, prices are probably going to stay the same as the last two weeks," a trader said.
"Supplies from South Korea in February are expected at around 6-7 cargoes, similar to January volumes," the trader said.
Mideast cargoes seen arriving late January was mostly placed into the bunker market, they said.
A local trader was heard planning to move a very large crude carrier to southern China in late January out of Singapore to meet Chinese demand.
Asking prices into south China were indicated at $7.50-$8.00 per tonne over Singapore spot quotes on a cost-and-freight basis.
While one to two local traders were expected to support prices, traders said such efforts were likely to be limited as supplies remained sufficient to meet demand.
